business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. At least 15 submissions written and oral to the Senate legislation inquiry into the Child Care Payments Bill drew attention to the administrative difficulties the government was forcing on the industry. Why did the government ignore those views and go ahead with its changes to the system of payments of child-care assistance? Why did the government cause chaos in the child-care industry and cause chaos for parents by pushing through changes which it has now reversed and which it has now decided it can delay for a further 30 months?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Neal for the question. Here we go again, Madam President, beating up an issue that is false—
—She nailed you.

—She has not nailed me at all, Senator Cook; she has nailed herself. I accept that interjection and point out to Senator Cook that Senator Neal has nailed herself because she has come up with an untrue premise. There have been submissions to the Senate inquiry—even recent media articles covering submissions to the Senate inquiry—that suggested only that dramatic increases in child-care fees and community centres are forcing parents, especially women, to change their work patterns. The Labor Party created an unsustainable child-care system whilst in government, and that is why I say Senator Neal has nailed herself because the system that the Labor Party brought into existence was unsustainable. Irresponsibly, it allowed centres to set up where they liked with no regard to need, creating an oversupply and problems of undersupply as well.

answer.para: The Howard government has allocated more money to child care than any previous government. There has been an 18 per cent increase in this year alone from the last year of the Labor government. This government is about targeting assistance to low and middle income families, in particular the battlers, not those like Senator Neal—and I can understand why she is concerned—but those who need it most, in providing equity and choice in child care. Before the removal of the operational subsidy to community based centres who provide child care for approximately 1.5 per cent of Australian children, some 70,000 families received the benefit of around $20 a week no matter what their income, while 210,000 families around Australia in private centres did not. Why should someone on $75,000—as Senator Neal—or $100,000 income receive the same assistance from government as someone who is on, say, $28,000?

To demonstrate the government's commitment to helping families in the work force, child-care assistance will now be provided to families using outside school hours care services from 27 April. Fifty-one thousand low and middle income families will receive financial assistance for the first time, and 19,000 families will receive improved assistance. The government has provided substantial assistance, over $8 million, to community based centres to assist them restructure. Child-care fees are set by service providers. Those community based centres choosing to increase their fees do so in consultation with families and management. Many are choosing not to keep their fees at reasonable levels.

Private sector fees are now on average $10 a week less than community sector fees—$152 a week compared to $162 a week. Accreditation standards are identical in both sectors. Ninety per cent of private centres and ninety-two per cent of community based centres achieved accreditation. Finally, assertions that parents are withdrawing from the labour force due to fee increases are not supported by the Australian Bureau of Statistics' data.

talk.start.para: —They are!

—They are not supported by the data, but do not let the facts intrude on your own argument where you are trying to boost something up. The Australian Bureau of Statistics' data on women with dependent children show that their participation rates have remained stable, at around 59 per cent over the last two years. They are incontrovertible facts. As I said, facts do not worry the Labor Party. If they want to beat up an issue, they will do so regardless of the facts.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Herron, I do not think you even listened to the question. You read out a brief that your department had prepared in anticipation of a question about Catherine Cusack which did not come. What I asked you is why you changed the system of payment of child-care assistance last November with the Child Care Payments Bill when you are now reversing this with your Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill causing chaos in the industry. In the estimates hearing you said that you were changing your mind because of what parents and child-care centres had told you. Why did you not listen before you introduced the new system, not afterwards when you created chaos?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —We always listen to everybody who puts forward submissions to the government, unlike the ideologues on the other side who have their own philosophical basis which does not allow them to listen to people. We went out and sought advice from child-care providers, from parents and from the industry itself, and we have acted on that. That upsets the Labor Party because we have actually done something. We fixed the problems that they created. We listened to the people who put forward submissions, and we have adjusted them as we are supposed to do. That is what good government does. We will always do that when we listen to the constituents and do what is best for the constituency, not those high fliers who are on high incomes like Senator Neal, who finds it incompatible with her own position.
—That is outrageous.
—Senator Cook might not like that, but they are the facts of the matter. We listen to the battlers.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. In the last week as a result of the Howard government's responsible economic management we have seen further positive indications on employment growth; improved business expectations for sales, employment and investment; a surge in export growth in our non-traditional markets; and, yesterday, a massive cut to interest rates for small business. How is the environment on low interest rates, low inflation, reduced debt and strong business investment assisting small business and families?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —All Australians are benefiting from the sound economic management of the Howard government. The small business interest rate decision of Westpac yesterday was truly historic. Reducing the base rate to 7.2 per cent—down to rates that have not existed since the early 1970s—is a tremendous boost to small business in this country. Small business have been looking for this for so long. But, of course, 13 years of Labor gave them nothing but misery. Labor never understood small business. We will never forget—and small business will never forget—that under Mr Keating interest rates were forced up to something like 20 per cent for small business, obviously resulting in so many going to the wall. That was Labor's achievement of 1989-90—20 per cent interest rates for small business.
—1989-90! Come off it!

—And when we came to office, Senator Cook, it was 11.25 per cent for small business. Only two years later interest rates are down to 7.25 per cent, a four per cent improvement for all small business in this country. That is something of which we are very proud. And we give credit to Westpac for taking the lead. We would now like to see other banks in Australia pick up the challenge and provide competition to Westpac in this instance. We give credit in exactly the same way that we gave credit to the National Australia Bank when it led in the reduction of housing interest rates. Housing interest rates in this country are down to a 30-year low as well. All Australians benefit when the housing interest rate is at a 30-year low. We achieved that in housing; we achieved that for Australian families and we are now achieving it for Australian business as well.

answer.para: It has been estimated that Westpac's move will cut between $150 million and $400 million off the annual borrowing costs of small business around Australia—a tremendous boost. Huge money is being saved by small business: for an ordinary small business with a $100,000 overdraft the estimate is a saving of $275 a month. This did not come about by accident. It came about because we had a government in this country that had the courage to take the hard decisions on public expenditure—rein in public expenditure—get inflation down and allow it to flow through with lower interest rates to the benefit of all small business. Compare the figures—housing interest rates were at their high under Labor.
Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They were 17 per cent, Senator Bolkus. Now under this government they are 6.9 per cent. As I said, small business: a high under Labor of 20 per cent; under the coalition, 7.2 per cent. Credit card interest rates: a high under Labor of 25 per cent; now down to 16.2 per cent and still falling. And, of course, this translates into more jobs for Australians. This is part of the reason that an extra 220,000 jobs have been created since the Howard government came to office. And if the Labor Party had not blocked the reforms to the unfair dismissal laws last week, according to the Small Business Association another 50,000 Australians could have been employed. So there is no comparison in Australian politics at the moment on the issue of sound economic management. There is no comparison in the alternative that will benefit small business and give small business the opportunity to grow and expand and, most importantly, to employ. This good news is for the benefit of all Australians. (Time expired)

—Madam President, as a result of Senator Hill's comprehensive and exciting answer, I have a supplementary question. How will desperately needed reform of Australia's taxation system also assist small business? Is the minister aware of recent support for the government's proactive approach to taxation reform?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —Tax reform is one of the three great areas of reform in which we can help contribute to more Australian jobs. We have done it with the economy by addressing the $10.3 billion deficit we inherited and achieving these low interest rates. We have done it with IR—industrial relations—reform and it produced the lowest level of days lost in one year in 70 years. And we will do it in tax reform as well. We know that it is an area in which we can reduce the costs to small business again. But you asked me to compare it with others. Where does the Labor Party stand on tax reform? On 21 May last year Mr Evans said, `It is only a second or third order issue.' What did Senator Cook say in this place? He said, `There is a case for tax reform but not the overblown case that the government has made out.' At last the Labor Party is starting to come clean. Mr Latham has spilt the beans; he says, `Taxation reform is critically urgent,' and he is right. (Time expired)

answer.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Cook! If you had not been shouting so much, the minister would have heard me call him to order because the time for answering the question had expired.

—My question is to Senator Herron representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. The Returned Services League of Australia, in a submission to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee inquiry into public dental services, has called for the reinstatement of an accessible public dental health program for those who find basic dental care beyond their means. Do you, Minister, support the call by the RSL veterans and other needy Australians for access to basic dental care?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I am keen to answer this question because I want to nail Senator Campbell on this, as a matter of fact. The Commonwealth dental health program was a desperate bid for votes in the ALP's 1993 election campaign. The ALP made no com mitment whatsoever to further funding of the program in the last budget of their administration in 1995-96, and Senator Campbell might not be aware of that. That is why they sold him the dump on this question: he was not aware of the history of the thing. Nor is Senator Campbell aware that there was no commitment made by the Labor Party in their 1996 election campaign—not one commitment, Senator Campbell. In fact, the program achieved the aim set by the former minister, Dr Lawrence, of treating 1.5 million people by December 1996 and the program then ceased—under the Labor Party, Madam President—six months before it was due to expire.

answer.para: Despite the posturing of state authorities on this issue, the indications were that the Commonwealth dental health program was always going to cease at the conclusion of the agreements with the states in June 1997. The Commonwealth dental health program was a Commonwealth intervention in what is traditionally a state responsibility, as I said to Senator Crowley yesterday. Its aim was to assist the states in alleviating a backlog of service demand and to set the states up for longer term reforms. In the light of overall priorities, the government decided that continuing Commonwealth—

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Madam President: Senator Herron was asked a specific question: did he agree with the comments made by the RSL? Senator Herron has spent the last 2½ minutes giving a rather distorted history of the Commonwealth dental health program. Could you ask him to actually answer the question he was asked that he either agrees or disagrees with the RSL?
—There is no point of order.
—I am one of the few members of this chamber who has been a member of the armed forces and I am happy to relate that.
—Answer the question.
—How many of you have on that side? Are there any?
—Senator Herron! You should stick to the question.
—Madam President, I was making the point—
—The level of noise is too high. I ask senators to abide by the standing orders.

—I was making the point that it was a state responsibility, as was recognised by the Labor government when they were in power. The aim of the program was to assist the states in alleviating the backlog of service demand to set the states up for longer term reforms. It is correct there are certain representations made by different bodies. As you know, Madam President, we have put more funding into Veterans' Affairs which covers those issues that Senator Forshaw is already mentioning.

answer.para: In the light of overall priorities, the government decided that continued Commonwealth supplementary funding was not warranted. Of course, states always welcome additional Commonwealth funding to meet their responsibilities, but in this case we took a decision in the light of budgetary circumstances and the need to focus on prime Commonwealth roles in the health sector. States gained efficiencies in the delivery of their dental services during the period of Commonwealth funding. They should now be in a good position to continue to deliver appropriate services. So I suggest to those people who made those applications that they approach the respective state governments, whose responsibility it is to provide dental services.

As I have said already, we have put extra funding into services for repatriation benefits as well, so it is a state responsibility. We inherited a $10½ billion deficit when we came into government and no responsible government would have taken any other direction but to try to balance the budget. It was in that context that there was that promise of the Labor Party—they stopped providing funds and we did not continue them. So we have produced a situation now where we expect to have a balanced budget, unlike the $10½ billion deficit that was produced by the Labor Party, so they have no credentials in this regard at all.

talk.start.para: —Don't read the questions they give you, George.

—When you become a minister, Kay, I will ask the questions of you. I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you aware that, in evidence given to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee inquiry into dental services, it was said that waiting lists for basic dental care have now blown out to an average of two years? Are you aware that public hospitals are being required to treat more patients for emergency dental procedures due to the lack of a public dental care program such as the Commonwealth dental health program? Given the pressures on public hospitals due to your failed health policies, will you reinstate the CHDP?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I was aware that some evidence was given—to answer Senator Campbell's question—but I am pleased to say that some states have taken up their responsibility. In particular, I am advised that my own state of Queensland has provided an additional $19.8 million, and this included $352,000 to attract and retain dentists in rural Queensland—unlike the Labor government. When they were in power, they did not take any of those initiatives, nor is the New South Wales government currently doing anything about it. So, Senator Campbell, your question was incorrect in the sense that it is not all states. As I am proud to say, my own state of Queensland has provided extra funding and Senator Boswell would be pleased to know that it has been weighted to the rural communities. My own colleague Senator Ian Macdonald is aware that they have weighted it to rural communities so as to overcome the backlogs. But, Senator Campbell, you should be aware that it is a state responsibility after all.
—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer the minister to Mr Mark Latham's comments on A Current Affair last night where he said:

question.para: We will never see those high marginal tax rates in Australia ever again. We will never see them up to around 60 per cent because Australia needs an internationally competitive tax system to attract investment and jobs.

Minister, do you agree with Mr Latham? Do you believe that the need for a competitive tax system to attract investment and jobs justifies the government's policy to reform the current tax system? Is there anybody left anywhere who truly believes that there is no need to reform the current tax system?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Ferris, for that very important question. I must say in reference to Mr Latham that it is very good to see a member of the Labor Party attempting to make a constructive contribution to the tax reform debate.

answer.para: Senator George Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am coming to you in a minute, Senator George Campbell, so just hold on. I do agree with Mr Latham that Australia needs an internationally competitive tax system which encourages investment and jobs. I also agree with that part of his book—to be launched, I understand, by the Leader of the Opposition—which says this:

answer.para: Whereas the top marginal rates in Australia in the 1950s cut in at 19 times the level of average weekly earnings, the ratio has now fallen to 1.5.

As the Treasurer, Mr Costello, has indicated, this statement bears a striking resemblance to one in another book called The Australian Taxation System: In Need of Reform . I think many members of the public are obtaining copies of this. I would certainly like to welcome the fact that Mr Latham is making a contribution to the tax reform debate. What a change it is for the Labor Party to have someone who is making a contribution. He has recognised, as many on the other side have not recognised, the shortfalls of the system. In that context we welcome the contribution.

I do not think it would be drawing too long a bow, Senator Cook, to suggest from his statements that we have a second-class tax system. I know Senator Cook has difficulties with that, but I think it would not be drawing too long a bow. Despite the fact that there are many members of the frontbench, including Mr Beazley, including former senator Gary Evans, the shadow Treasurer, who are opposed to any concept of tax reform, there are other members of the Labor Party who have made a contribution. Lindsay Tanner was one who said this. Everyone is laughing now at a shadow minister, Lindsay Tanner.

talk.start.para: —He is one of the young Turks.
—He is one of the young Turks; you are quite right. He said:

answer.para: Faced with the threat of the income tax system unravelling and inequity escalating as this unravelling accelerates, Labor must examine genuine alternative foundation stones for our tax system.
I think it is also clear that Mr Tanner believes we have a second-rate tax system.

Another Labor thinker on tax reform is Senator George Campbell. Out of deference to Senator Campbell, I do not wish to embarrass him today and refer to his comments made in the Financial Review last year in relation to an expenditure tax. Of course, we have had the shadow Treasurer, Mr Gary Evans, talking about death duties and talking about abolishing negative gearing. We have two classes in the Labor Party: we have the smaller class of people who believe we must have tax reform, people like George Campbell, people like Tanner, people like Mark Latham; and we have another group of people who are utterly opposed to any sense of tax reform.

talk.start.para: —Tell us what your reform proposals are.

—We seem to have someone on that side who comes down hard on both sides of the fence on tax reform, and that person happens to be Senator Cook. If there is a supplementary, I will explain why. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I have a supplementary question to Senator Kemp. Can he further explain the benefits of tax reform and comment on those who support that view?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Thank you for that follow-up question, Senator Ferris. Senator Cook, as I said, has come down hard on both sides of the fence on the tax debate recently. This is which Senator Cook said yesterday:

answer.para: I have not said, and repeat this, that we have a first-rate tax system in Australia.
That is what Senator Cook said. So he started off all right, but then he went on to say this:
What I have said, for the record, is to reject the Treasurer's assertion that Australia has a second-class tax system.

So you do not say we have a first-class system and you do not accept what the Treasurer says, that we have a second-class system. Do we have a third-class system, Senator Cook, or what are you talking about?

talk.start.para: —Read the whole quote.
—That is the very problem of the Labor Party—they do not know where they stand on tax reform. No wonder Senator Faulkner is embarrassed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, Senator Herron. Do you recall telling me on 25 November, in relation to a question about a survey by the New South Wales Council of Social Service and a previous survey done by the National Council of Community Based Children's Services, all of which showed grave problems in the child-care area, that they need not be taken seriously? In light of the survey published in February by the Queensland Child Care Coalition, which represents both private and community based centres, showing that 65 per cent of respondents had increased their fees in the last six months by an average of $11 a week per child, and that at the same time child-care assistance had reduced by $9.70 a week per child, do you now acknowledge that there is a problem?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —No, I do not. Senator Neal will have to do a lot better than this if she is going to beat Jim Lloyd when she stands in the other place. I do not know why people want to get out of this place.
—Senator Herron, I draw your attention to the question.

—I answered it right at the beginning, Madam President. I said no, I do not agree. I cannot be more explicit than that. I said that I do not agree and now I want to elaborate and fill out the answer so I can get a little more detail to it.
—I bet you can't take up the four minutes.

—I will take you on. The fact of the matter is that preliminary 1997 child-care census data collected in August last year shows that the average weekly fee for families using full-time care in community centres is about $162, an increase of 9.5 per cent over 1996, and the fee in private centres is $152, an increase of one per cent over 1996.

answer.para: Senator Neal asked whether I recall giving an answer about that. Yes, I do recall, and I stand by that. It is all very well, Senator Neal, to pull out percentages. Eight out of 10 you would say is 80 per cent. That is what most of those surveys—

talk.start.para: —You do not make any sense.

—She is struggling with that. She cannot quite grasp that. When you talk about percentages you are talking about numbers out of 100, Senator Neal. I just thought I would tell you that because you do not seem to have grasped that. I remember pointing out in November last year this survey worked out to be 0.02 or 0.04 per cent of the numbers that were surveyed. It was a survey done by the New South Wales government where they asked people who were dissatisfied to ring in. So it was not only selective but also an attempt to discredit the government's position.

answer.para: I am not aware of the third survey that Senator Neal referred to. Perhaps she will come back to me in a supplementary and elaborate on that so that I can be made aware of it. The overall average weekly fee in full-time care and long day care centres is $155. The 1997 increase in fees in community centres is above the trend over the last six years but has seen increases of around six per cent—or between $6 to $10 per year for families using full-time care. The increase in fees in private centres is below this trend.

So the government provided financial assistance—$8.3 million over two years—to assist community centres adjust to the loss of operational subsidy. Only 48 per cent of centres have claimed this assistance to date. I think that gives the answer in full to the question. Only 48 per cent have claimed this assistance.

talk.start.para: —Is that 48 out of 100?

—Yes, Senator Faulkner, out of 100. Fee structures are set by service providers, not by government. Child-care fees are influenced by several factors—movements in award wages; service charging practices; changes to state regulations; or increases in overheads such as rates, insurance, utilities, hours of opening, number of children attending, et cetera. But that might be too much for Senator Neal to comprehend. They are the factors that influence all this.

answer.para: The government is concerned that fees continue to rise and has announced a review of service charging practices in consultation with service providers over the next year. The government is still committed to maintaining quality of child care. There is no crisis. This is another attempt to beat up a crisis, which is what Senator Neal, going for a seat in the lower house, is doing. Why she does this, I do not know. Perhaps she is being outshone by the other members on the other side. But for whatever reason—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I must say that I am a bit astonished that you are unaware of a survey that was done in your own state by the Queensland Child Care Coalition. But one of those surveyed—and it is a privately run centre—said:

question.para: The cost to parents on maximum Child Care Assistance increased as follows: One child from $25.40 per week to $44.50 per week, two children from $30.40 to $72 per week. As we had a large number of single parent families the increase could not be borne with children being removed from care. Some parents ceased employment.
Do you still say, Minister, despite all the evidence, there is no problem?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —There is no crisis. There are problems, no doubt, for individual people. I would like to see the Queensland Child Care Coalition survey. I will not comment on that because I have not seen it. I am always very careful of surveys done by coalitions under the aegis of the Labor Party—
—Don't touch the coalition with a 40-foot barge pole!

—Because it is usually a Labor Party front. I do not know this. I will inquire into that and provide Senator Neal with a breakdown of the statistics. I fear she does not understand statistics. So I will provide a breakdown of those figures for her to see whether there is validity to that statement. But, of course, there will be outlays at every end of the spectrum in any situation when government services are being provided. You can always drag out a person, or two people, or three or a number of others who are going to be adversely affected. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, I want to test the Prime Minister's boast that the sale of Telstra will help make Australia the largest shareholding democracy in the world. Isn't it the case that between November last year and March this year the percentage of shares owned by the top 10 shareholders in Telstra has almost trebled, rising from 10½ per cent to 28½ per cent in just four months? Haven't nearly 300,000 so-called `mums and dads' already sold out of Telstra—adding to the 11 million `mums and dads' who did not invest in the first place? Isn't it the case that the overwhelming majority of `mums and dads' have simply not shared in the Telstra magic pudding? Haven't they, given the $8 billion undervaluation by your government, simply lost money as the value is transferred to a reducing number of professional, local and foreign investors?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —We make no apology for the one-third sale of Telstra. That was an election promise which became the central issue of the last election and which we won with a record majority. We have delivered that promise in full, despite the efforts of the Democrats and the Labor Party to attempt to make us break that promise.

answer.para: Senator Woodley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, Senator. The one-third sale of Telstra has been widely welcomed. Many Australians have taken the chance to become shareholders in Telstra and many Australians, through their superannuation funds, have also got an indirect share of Telstra. This has been a float which has been extremely widely welcomed. It was a promise which we made to the Australian people and which we have delivered in full with major benefits for all Australians. Despite the very clear acceptance by Australians of this Telstra sale, it is a great pity that the Democrats still are prepared to oppose this important initiative.

answer.para: The position of the employees of Telstra really worried the Labor Party. We can all remember that they wanted to get the trade union bosses to fight the sale of Telstra. As distinct from the trade union bosses, the trade union members bought up very handsomely in Telstra. I think at least over 90 per cent of employees of Telstra bought shares. Many Australians have become shareholders in Telstra, and when we follow through the recent announcement that the Prime Minister made on the sale of Telstra, undoubtedly many more Australians will take up the opportunity to become shareholders in this truly great enterprise. Senator, if you adopted a more constructive policy in this area, it is even possible your polls might rise from two per cent nationwide. So I would urge you to rethink your policies and get behind this very important initiative that Mr Howard has announced.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I will try again to get an answer, Minister. What we are looking for are the real winners. As we look at what happened the first time, I have to ask you, Minister: was it the foreign—

question.para: Government senators—No, no!

talk.start.para: —Senators on my right at the end of the chamber will refrain from interjecting.

—Minister, we are looking for the real winners. Were they the foreign investors who cashed out their shares for a $420 million profit within the first few days of buying them? Were they the stockbrokers and merchant bankers who won $280 million in fees and are lining up for some $900 million this time? Or was it the 85 per cent of Australians who never owned Telstra shares but who will have to fund the budget shortfall caused by your selling the first third at $8 billion less than it was really worth?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Let me tell you who the real winners are: the real winners with the sale of Telstra are the Australian people. In relation to the sale, you will be aware that the Commonwealth will be able to retire a very substantial amount of debt run up by the Labor government. Of course, this will be a very substantial saving for all taxpayers. In conclusion, Senator, I would urge you to recognise that your polls are not travelling well and that people are thinking your policies are old-fashioned. As I said in my earlier response, I urge you to get behind this extremely important initiative that the Prime Minister has announced.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I refer to the current health crisis, a crisis that has been devastating to my home state of Tasmania, and ask: given that the Tasmanian health minister, Peter McKay, has described your Tasmanian liberal colleagues as `parrots', when will the government acknowledge that the mindless repetition of the party line is no substitute for action on the crisis facing health in this country?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Mackay for the question because it is a very good question, unlike a lot of the other questions that have been given to me. I have to confess to my backbench here that I succumbed to the temptation to look up Senator Crowley's speeches, and I apologise to them in advance because this is relevant in answering Senator Mackay's question. Senator Murphy, sitting on the backbench on 9 November 1994, asked:

answer.para: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. The minister will be aware of an article in today's Australian entitled `Hospital sends bills to feds' which alleges illegal cost shifting by the Victorian state government in the area of health. Can the minister inform the Senate what the government is doing to bring an end to this practice of cheating the system and ensure that states accept their health responsibilities?

Senator HILL

When we in fact looked at the figures for Victoria as compared with the former program of the Labor Party—a small program but nevertheless, one could say, built upon the same principles—we found that exactly the same percentage went to exactly the same areas, which demonstrated that the money went where it should be going.

answer.para: What was the Labor Party's response to that? I also do not apologise that as a result of examining the state assessment panels' view—of course assessment panels tended to have a very strong state agency influence—less money went to state agencies and more money went to community groups. talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you explain or define what you meant by `overwhelmingly, we accepted their recommendations'? talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

Of course, that body was appointed by the states. It would make recommendations to a state government, which then would make recommendations to the Commonwealth.

answer.para: We indicated from the start the sorts of matters that we would be taking into account when we evaluated a state's recommendation. talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank Senator Synon for that question. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the Prime Minister and the Premier of Victoria signed a regional forest agreement for the central highlands of Victoria last Friday. This is the third forest region that is now covered by such an agreement following the signing of RFAs in East Gippsland and for all of Tasmania last year.

answer.para: This is in stark contrast to the record of the previous Labor government. Between 1992 and 1996 Labor failed to secure a single regional forest agreement. In fact, Labor's forest policy was a complete joke. I am sure we will all recall the great blockade of Parliament House, as well as the public brawl between Minister Beddall and Senator Faulkner.

We remember that the former Prime Minister told us that 509 forest coupes would be protected because of their high conservation value. The list was provided by Senator Faulkner. Unfortunately, he put high conservation value on flora that did not even exist. They were phantoms. The list also included areas that has been clear-felled, as well as pine and eucalypt plantations.

The Howard government has now finalised three agreements. By the end of 1999, all forest agreements that produce export woodchips will be covered by RFAs—all in three years; nothing done in four years by the previous Labor government.

The central highlands RFA is a win for both jobs and the environment. It is a win for jobs in the communities of the central highlands because this 20-year agreement will provide the security that industry needs to expand and invest in value-adding operations.

The agreement opens the way for the creation of over 300 new jobs between now and 2006. We have agreed to set up a $28 million hardwood timber industry development restructuring program for Victoria which will cover all the RFA regions in the state.

The agreement is also a win for the environment. One hundred and sixteen thousand hectares have been added to the central highlands reserve system. This represents a 64 per cent increase in the reserve system and it means that almost half of the public land in the region is now protected in reserves.

Through the agreement, the Commonwealth and Victoria have fully met their national reserve criteria for the regional forest agreement process. The three regional forest agreements that have been signed by the Howard government have laid the basis for over 1,700 jobs in regional Australia and have conserved over half a million hectares of forest.
Madam President, the central highlands regional forest agreement will create jobs, protect the environment and I commend it to the Senate.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —In accordance with the order of the Senate of 9 March 1998, I table today two documents relating to the proposed Multilateral Agreement on Investment. The first is a draft Multilateral Agreement on Investment (MAI) as at 13 February 1998. The second is Australia's latest revised schedule of preliminary reservations dated October 1997. I also seek leave to incorporate a short statement in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
MULTILATERAL AGREEMENT ON INVESTMENT

I table today two documents relating to the proposed Multilateral Agreement on Investment (MAI). The first is the draft Multilateral Agreement on Investment (MAI), as at 13 February 1998. The second is Australia's latest Revised Schedule of Preliminary Reservations, dated October 1997.

It should be emphasised that the two documents are very much in draft form. The negotiations on the MAI are far from complete as is evidenced by the significant number of square bracketed provisions and alternative formulations in the draft. Many significant issues are yet to be settled, including the nature of the dispute resolution mechanism, the extent of any so-called "carve outs", the treatment of regional economic integration organisations and the nature of and processes for exceptions. Accordingly, negotiations are not likely to conclude for some time. The OECD Ministerial Council Meeting (MCM) in late April 1998 will need to decide the future of the negotiations on the MAI, including whether to extend the deadline for negotiations, for example to next year's MCM.

Given the nature of the MAI negotiations, countries' lists of exceptions, or reservations, will form an integral part of the agreement. Australia's draft reservations should therefore be included in any assessment of the draft agreement. I stress that Australia's draft reservations are likely to be significantly revised and refined as the negotiations proceed, reflecting:
. further development of the provisions of the MAI, possibly involving significant changes;

. the outcome of ongoing consultations with Commonwealth and State agencies as regards the application of MAI provisions and policies that may impose more stringent requirements on foreign investors than on domestic investors, for which we will need to take reservations; and

. the outcome of negotiations on the form that country specific reservations should take and the types of reservations that will apply, including with respect to the question of applying standstill to particular reservations.

The Government believes that an appropriately worded MAI could provide benefits to Australia. For example, Australians who invest overseas would benefit from a more transparent and certain global investment framework and Australian offshore investments will be more secure because of the protection offered by the MAI. Australia would also benefit from the higher global investment promoted by an MAI. Strong global investment is critical to generating high levels of economic growth over the longer-term, and brings benefits from the creation of jobs, from higher income and from new technology.

The Government will not sign the agreement unless it is satisfied that it is in Australia's national interest to do so. In protecting Australia's national interest, the Government has stated that it will ensure that any agreement on the MAI will not override, or weaken, Australia's existing policies on foreign investment. Australia will lodge all exceptions required to protect current policies. For example, exceptions would be taken out in the areas of foreign investment, immigration and indigenous people. Australia is negotiating on the basis that general exceptions would apply to such things as tax measures, national security, public order and health and quarantine measures. Foreign investors operating in Australia would continue to be required to adhere to Australia's domestic laws and regulations, including our environmental and labour standards.

In conducting the negotiations, the Government is actively consulting with interested parties, including the States and Territories, business groups, the union movement and other non-government organisations.

The draft MAI has been referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties for examination. The Committee has called for submissions and will undertake public hearings in most capital cities. For those who have expressed concerns regarding the MAI, the Committee process provides an opportunity to comment on the draft agreement and Australia's draft exceptions. The Government will carefully consider all issues raised by interested parties and the general public in participating in the ongoing negotiation of the MAI. The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties aims to produce an interim report on the draft agreement by 25 May 1998.

The Government will not take binding action on the MAI until it has been subjected to the new treaty-making processes established by this Government in 1996. These processes require treaties to be tabled in Parliament along with a National Interest Analysis (and thus subject to public and parliamentary scrutiny) before the Government takes binding action. This process also requires that the views of the States and Territories be taken into account before Australia agrees to become a party to, or indicate its acceptance of, the treaty.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

The document read as follows—

SENATOR CROWLEY: My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, do you recall me personal guarantee by Prime Minister Howard in February 1996 when he stated:

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN

talk.start.para: —Yesterday during question time I was asked a question by Senator Chris Evans relating to the government members' secretariat and I wanted to add to the answer I provided yesterday. It is recorded in Hansard that I said:

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) to a question without notice asked by Senator Neal today, relating to child care.

This government has certainly created chaos in the child care arena. Despite the fact that Senator Herron seems to be incapable of appreciating that this is the case, certainly the rest of the community, families and women who have to take advantage of child care are very well aware of it.

You might have noted that this government has a history of refusing to acknowledge that they have problems. You might recall what occurred with nursing homes and what is happening now in the health system. This government believes that, if they consistently deny that there are any difficulties, that in fact there are none. But the community is a lot smarter than you. What Senator Herron and the government are saying is completely contrary to every piece of evidence that is available.

Three surveys have been done. On each occasion the minister has said that they are not to be taken seriously. He said that with the National Council of Community Based Children's Services, when they did a survey. He said that the New South Wales Council of Social Service survey should not be taken seriously. He said the Queensland Child Care Coalition survey should not be taken seriously. But these surveys all say very much the same thing, and when a number of surveys and people in the community are saying the same thing, that child care is in chaos, then I really think it would be worthwhile for this government to start listening. What they are saying is all the same; they are saying that child-care costs are going up all around Australia—they are going up between $11 and $25 a week per child.

The surveys are also saying that parents can no longer afford child care. The parents are being forced to either leave the work force or, alternatively, risk their children by putting them in unlicensed care. They are also saying that parents are being forced to expect a lower level of service because of the cuts the child-care centres are having to impose. They are having to reduce the number of trained staff; they are having to reduce the equipment that is available to them.

All round, child-care centres are doing it tough. The refusal of this government and Senator Herron to recognise that is not going to make the problem go away because, on the twentieth of this month, the inquiry being conducted by the Senate community affairs committee indicated that the concern about the chaos in child care is not limited to three surveys. We have now received 850 submissions from child-care centres, from parents and from community groups that, once again, say the same thing: the changes that have taken place as a result of this government's policy are a disaster; they are causing chaos all around Australia for parents and their families. In this day and age, it is pretty difficult to raise a family. With the increased costs being introduced by this government, it is not just pretty difficult, but if you are also trying to meet the cost of child care then, for many people, it really is impossible.

I have to say that I was quite surprised to receive, as one of the submissions received by the community affairs committee, a submission by Catherine Cusack. Catherine Cusack I have known for many years and she is a very thoughtful and considered person. But I suppose it also interesting that Catherine Cusack is an adviser to Peter Collins, the Liberal Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales. Catherine Cusack was very forthright about what she thought about the policies of this government in child care and the damage that is being done by the policies of this government to parents and their families. I would just like to read a small part of her submission, but I am sure most of the people in the Senate would like to hear much more of it. It is available and I hope that you will take the opportunity. She says:
During the period from 7 April to 1 July 1997, the costs of my child care for two children increased by $93.55.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is typical of Labor: fear mongering, scaring, saying there are crises when there are not crises. This is all they are capable of doing—no policies, no ideas. Under Labor, child care growth was unchecked and unsustainable, and that was one of the other things that contributed to the $10 billion deficit that we were left. They were spending more money than they actually were getting in revenue. Living on the never-never, that was typical of Labor.

speech.para: They had no formal planning system for child care, resulting in some areas having an oversupply of places and others being totally undersupplied. They focused the majority of their assistance on the community based sector, which supplied only about 30 per cent of child care places. That resulted in an uneven playing field for the industry.

They left us with a legacy of mess, total lack of planning, total lack of facilities spread across where they were needed, oversupply in one area and undersupply in another area. The child-care industry was in disarray under Labor's poor management. From 1991, private child care centres were established in various locations. They were established with no directional support from government to indicate areas of greatest need and there was haphazard growth all over the country. There were, as I said, too many centres existing in one area, where there were no centres in another area—total undersupply.

This poorly planned access to child care created uncertainty in the child-care industry about their future viability due to too many centres in some areas, and it meant a lack of choice for other families in undersupplied areas.

Under Labor the low rate of child-care assistance provided to families outside school hours meant there was totally inadequate supply of places for children requiring care between the end of school and when their parents came home from work. That was totally inadequate to meet the needs of low- and middle-income families. So they effectively prevented about 51,000 Australian families using outside school hours care from receiving any child care assistance at all. That was neglected. But do not worry about that, they left us a system which was totally in disarray and which also neglected a whole range of families that needed after school care.

In one of the questions, Senator Mackay went on about surveys. Let me tell you about one of the surveys done in South Australia last week. They claimed there were huge fee increases and that the centres were closing down, and women were having to leave work because they could not get child care. This survey was done by the Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union, so I do not think that was an unbiased group of people doing the survey. I think it showed that the fees went up about $4 above those of the private centres. Also, when you look at what has happened in South Australia, overall, the restructuring there has been a net loss of two centres.

Money was given by the government to centres which did not see themselves as being viable—ones which, because of Labor's poor planning, were totally inappropriately placed. They were given assistance for restructuring. If they could not restructure, they were given assistance for combining some of those services together.
The industry now is getting the measure of this Labor Party. The Australian Confederation of Child Care has issued a press release, which states:

Australian Child Care Centres are the best in the world, and are as economical as $5.00 per day to families, according to the Australian Confederation of Child Care which represents over 1000 private child care centres.

I would rather listen to them than to some survey done by the Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union because the confederation is actually in the business—it represents 1,000 centres. The press release also quotes the president of the confederation, Martin Kemp, as saying:
Studies of overseas child care centres recently undertaken by members of the Confederation have confirmed that Australia has the world's best standards and facilities.
We want to completely refute recent comments about Child Care which appear to be politically motivated—
Appear to be? I would say they are politically motivated—

which suggest there have been substantial fee increases. This politically motivated campaign only serves to do long term damage to the Child Care industry as a whole. This campaign is trying to blame the current Federal Government for reduc tions in attendance at Child Care Centres. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The confederation goes on to praise the current minister, saying that he has shown more understanding and leadership in child care than have ministers in previous times. This is damnation for all the previous child-care ministers on the other side, including Senator Crowley, who reigned over this raid that occurred in child care under Labor. This is just a furphy. The Labor Party has no policies on this issue. If Labor were back in power, we would have child-care centres being spawned in inappropriate places throughout Australia, like they were under Labor. talk.start.para: —I have never heard such a load of nonsense from Senator Patterson. I have a great deal of admiration for Senator Patterson in a number of areas where she has worked most effectively. But, after listening to her contribution this afternoon, I really think she needs to do some homework.

speech.para: I want to direct my attention to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. He has tried to discredit the Queensland Child Care Coalition survey by calling it a Labor Party front. I am sure that parents in Queensland will be interested to hear this because parents are concerned about the lack of child care, the costs of child care and the disturbing trends under this government. They are not concerned about Liberal, Labor, the National Party and the Democrats; they want quality child care.

Senator Patterson has acknowledged that Australia has had, and still has, the framework for a very effective child-care system. I would agree. Who delivered that system? It was Labor when it came into government in 1983. What concerns so many of us, Senator Paterson, is how your government is whittling away at what is a very good and recognised system.

When Senator Herron, who in this place acts for the minister responsible, says, `Look, only one or two are affected, and you always have people affected,' I ask: when did he last visit a child-care centre? He acknowledged that he had not read this report. I am sorry that he has left the chamber because this report is about his state of Queensland, and the survey was by both the community based and private child-care providers that Senator Patterson referred to earlier in regard to the survey report.

The Queensland child-care survey, released in February this year, found a disturbing downturn in quality child-care availability. This is one of the highlights: 3,255 Queensland children are estimated to be missing out on quality child care. That is why we are concerned. That is why parents are concerned. That is why child-care providers are concerned. Who is caring for those estimated 3,255 children who are missing out on quality child care?

The second point is that, because of child-care funding cuts, parents have been forced to reduce the hours of care by as much as 12,000 hours. This is what we know from just this particular survey: 12,000 quality child-care hours have gone missing because of the funding arrangements and changes that the government has introduced.

What about enrolments? Enrolments had decreased by 35 per cent in the first half of 1997 and by 50 per cent in the second half. I wonder what the figures are going to be for the first half of 1998 and the second half of 1998. The fee increase reported in the first half of 1997 was between 50c to $30 per week per child. That is alarming for families. No wonder they are withdrawing their children from child care. They cannot cope with that kind of increase in fees. The average fee increase for the second half of 1997 was $11 per week per child. Again, who can say what it will be for 1998 and, if this continues, the second half of 1998?
A community centre in Ipswich stated:

Mainly with fee increases, families have found it difficult as their wage had no rise to combat the rise in fees. Some parents were commenting about their security of employment. We are finding that the overall spirit of families is suffering as parents battle to meet costs not only with child care but elsewhere as well. Families are convinced that the government is determined to keep parents, particularly the mother, at home.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Reynolds has just made the statement that the government is forcing increased fees on child-care centres. That is absolute nonsense. The government does not set child-care fees. In the community sector, child-care fees and other management decisions are made by committees made up of the parents and the staff in the centres. The government gave community child-care centres over 12 months notice that the system was going to change and provided substantial support—$8.3 million over two years—to assist them to adjust to operating without untargeted subsidies. In addition, supplementary funding of $4.1 million annually is being provided to services in disadvantaged areas.

speech.para: So, far from forcing fee increases, the charges now in place have nothing to do with the government; they are set by the committees that are running these centres. Far from what Senator Reynolds would have us believe about the Labor government's record in terms of child-care centres, the truth of the matter is that the child-care program was out of control under the Labor government, with an oversupply in some areas, while families elsewhere had little access to the kind of child care they needed.

The Howard government has made vast improvements to the child-care program. In fact, it is providing more equitable access to child-care places for families all over Australia. We have addressed the concerns about child care that have been raised by Australian families and the child-care industry in extensive consultations, and we have addressed the unregulated growth in the industry over the last six years. In fact, the Howard government has introduced a child-care system which is fair to all parents. One might sum it up by saying—

talk.start.para: —Yes, it makes them all pay more.
—a fair go to all families is being given by the Howard government child-care program.

speech.para: There are six principles underlying the Howard government's child-care program—and I think I will run through those six principles for the benefit of senators on the other side, who I am sure will be enlightened by them.The first principle is that the government believes it should assist low and middle income families to meet the cost of child care. Currently, around 77 per cent of families using long day child care receive child-care assistance. Of these, 42 per cent receive the maximum level of assistance. That is a very good thing, and it is something of which the Howard government is very proud.

The government believes, secondly, that families in like circumstances should be treated in the same way. This commitment is seen in the recent decision to increase the amount of financial assistance again to low and middle income families using outside school hours care. Thirdly, the government believes that extra resources should be provided to help children with additional needs. Extra funding is available to provide child-care services with the support needed to care for children with high needs.

Fourthly—and this is something which I consider very important—the government believes that it should provide additional support for services in geographically disadvantaged areas, such as remote and rural communities. Why should the people who live in isolated regional towns in Australia not receive good child care? Why should this all go to the kind of inner-city metropolitan electorates which the Labor Party funded? This is now being done. The Howard government is very proud of the fact that it is subsidising child-care centres and helping them to operate in remote rural communities.

Fifthly, the government believes that priority for new places should be given to neighbourhoods and communities with insufficient places to meet demand. The sixth point and principle under which the government operates is that parents should be confident that a high standard of child care is being provided. The government has gone out of its way to ensure that standards are not only maintained but improved.

So, overall, it can be said that the Howard government has a very, very proud and outstanding record of achievement in the field of child care—and the Labor government has a lot to feel ashamed of in this area. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What we have just had from the other side is the greatest load of rubbish I have ever heard in my life. First off, we had Senator Herron trying desperately to answer questions about a situation he had absolutely no grasp of. Then we had Senator Patterson saying that the ALP was responsible for inadequate child-care facilities.

speech.para: Senator Patterson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Let me tell you, Senator Patterson, when I was a young mother, I lived for many, many years under a coalition government. There were very, very few child-care centres and, because of that, women like myself who came from working class areas and who had very little transport could not go out to work. But, if we did go out to work, it had to be part time and we had to work around child-care centres' hours, or stay at home. There was no choice. There were very, very few facilities. In fact, women like myself and millions of others in this country had to rely on their mothers, their mother-in-laws, the lady next door, or whatever. So do not tell me about child-care centres and adequate facilities.

speech.para: The ALP government brought in an extremely successful child-care program. Under your government, since you were elected in March 1996, you have turned this area into an absolute and utter disaster. Over the past two budgets, your government has decimated the child-care sector by removing $820 million. So how can you possibly say that you are providing a decent service?

These are some of the changes that you have brought about: you have abolished income allowed for additional dependent children when assessing eligibility for child-care assistance; you have removed operational subsidies worth $100 million over four years from community based child-care centres; you have reduced child-care assistance or put in place cut-offs for second and subsequent children; you have extended the range of fringe benefits for child-care assistance income testing; and you have removed operational subsidies to outside school hours care, putting in doubt the long-term viability of this flexible program—and let us talk about this particular aspect. Because of this, I do not think your government knows or understands how—

talk.start.para: —It does not want to know.

—Exactly, Senator Neal. You do not understand how the after hours school care operates. It operates on part-time, casual and volunteer labour. Because of your IR legislation you have forced people, particularly part-time and casual people, into a situation where they have to work when their boss tells them to work. They cannot operate their own part-time working hours. They have to work when they are told to work; otherwise they risk losing their job. How does this benefit those parents and those children when their parents have to work—

speech.para: Senator Eggleston interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Eggleston, it is a fact of life that in today's society both parents have to work to provide their children with an adequate and decent life. Most people in this country, if they are lucky enough to have work, need both parents working. With this particular outside school hours cut, we are going to go back to the situation of the latchkey kids, or these children will be at school unsupervised for hours and hours. Who wants to go back to the good old days of the latchkey kids?

speech.para: You also froze child-care assistance and child-care cash rebate ceilings for two years, which has meant no indexation for the past two years. These changes have created total confusion and uncertainty in the sector, particularly for parents and for service providers. Senator Reynolds touched on the Queensland Child Care Coalition survey in our home state of Queensland which revealed that 3,255 children have been removed from 244 services in Queensland in the last year as a result of the fee increases—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What really puzzles me about this debate is that Senators Neal and Gibbs, who are normally well-intentioned people, seem to be incapable of really looking at the causation of the so-called problems in child care. There is a recent article in the Daily Telegraph where commentator Miranda Devine examines in some detail the reasons for the much touted crisis in child care, which I certainly do not accept exists at all. It is very interesting because she quotes Lyn Farrell, the Director of Lady Gowrie Child Care Centre in Erskineville, who goes so far as to describe the so-called situation in child care as `precipitated by factors from changing work habits to the oversupply of centres.'

speech.para: She goes on to say that if you listen to the New South Wales community services minister, Fay Lo Po—and I would interpolate there, Senator Neal and those on the other side—the fault lies with the federal government which cuts operational subsidies to community based centres. The much touted surveys are referred to. Then Miranda Devine goes on to say—and I wholeheartedly endorse this—that the truth is much more complex. She says that there is a glut of child-care centres for two- to five-year-olds and refers to the pretty obvious fact that when the Labor federal government expanded child-care fee relief in 1991 it triggered an unplanned and unchecked explosion of child-care centres so that there was actually an oversupply of child-care centres when this government took office.

It meant that all sorts of entrepreneurial types—solicitors, merchant bankers and financial planners—said, `Get into child care; that is a good thing. There are plenty of subsidies for child care. It is a sure-fire money spinner.' In almost every area in Sydney, apart from the CBD and some isolated areas in the western suburbs, there is an oversupply of two- to five-year-old places. It is not just me saying so. Elizabeth Evans, a policy officer in the Department of Community Services, also says that. Before we get too excited about this, let us look at the causes of the problems in child care when we came to government. The private child-care centres had been established in locations with no direction, with no planning and with absolutely no support for looking at where child care was actually needed, that is, where the areas of greatest need were. The total chaos created was that created by Labor.

You need to look at what we are trying to achieve with our reforms. We are trying to put child care in locations where it is really needed. Secondly, we want to make it available for those children that need care where otherwise care was not available. Our child-care reforms are all about ensuring both fair and reasonable access to funded child care for more families rather than fewer families, to improved targeting for assistance to those families most in need—those in low income families that otherwise have no access to child care, those with children with disabilities that have no access to child care, and those children under two where there was almost no child care under Labor.

We now have a planning system to ensure that child-care services are established where families actually need them. Child care is now on a sustainable footing, which will help ensure that services grow at a rate to meet expected demand. We certainly have a commitment to build on the system of quality improvement across all service types. Our objective has been—and remains—to assist families with dependent children to participate in the work force and community by supporting the provision of affordable quality child care. What is most interesting of all is that the latest figures show that labour force participation by women with dependent children has remained constant since January 1996. (Time expired)
