talk.start.para: —I present the government's response to the report of the Community Affairs References Committee on the CJD settlement offer. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

para.inline: Recommendation 1. That the decision not to proceed with an epidemiological study be reconsidered. However, any future study should not be limited only to the Allars recommendation that it be undertaken in the context of monitoring past and possible cases of CJD in the recipient community.

speech.para: Response

The Government accepts this recommendation. The National Pituitary Hormones Advisory Council (NPHAC) will be asked to review its earlier decision and seek independent expert advice on the possible benefits of conducting a longitudinal study of hormone recipients.
Context

An epidemiological study of the pituitary hormone recipients was not conducted as recommended by Professor Allars following advice from the National Pituitary Hormone Advisory Council that there was no value to be gained from such a study. The Senate Community Affairs References Committee is proposing a wider study following an NHMRC report on the long-term effects on women of assisted conception.

para.inline: Recommendation 2. That the following areas of concern relating to the implementation of the Allars recommendations be addressed:

(a) Counselling—Ensure that the revised arrangements introduced in October 1996 to assist all recipients and their families who need counselling, are understood and are able to be accessed by all recipients. In particular, that these arrangements are quite distinct from, and alleviate the difficulties associated with those that have previously operated. In addition, that counsellors who may have been providing a service to the satisfaction of particular recipients are not precluded from assistance under the revised arrangements;

speech.para: Response

The Government accepts this recommendation. The next edition of the HPH newsletter will outline the counselling services currently available; the changes that have occurred from the previous arrangements and the process by which recipients or members of their family can seek counselling.
Context

Counselling services are available to all hormone recipients and their families to assist them to manage the risk of CJD in their lives. Counsellors require accreditation by an independent expert panel and each counselled person can receive only 15 sessions after which a review is conducted of their needs. The counselling services have changed several times since the scheme's inception in 1990.

para.inline: (b) Epidemiological study—That the decision not to conduct an epidemiological study be reconsidered, though any future study should proceed with broader objectives. (This is the subject of a separate recommendation);

speech.para: See Recommendation 1 above.

para.inline: (c) Tracing recipients—That renewed efforts be made to identify and trace remaining approved and unapproved recipients, with due sensitivity in recognition of the time which has elapsed since the Program concluded (This is also the subject of separate recommendations);

speech.para: Response

The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Department of Health and Family Services is currently pursuing avenues to identify unapproved hormone recipients and to trace the remaining recipients.
Context

Approximately 90.2% of approved recipients (i.e. 1784 of 1976) and 56% (i.e. 98 of 175) of the known unapproved recipients have been traced. The Department is investigating further strategies to identify and trace the remaining recipients.

para.inline: (d) Access to information—That treatment records and other information requested by recipients be provided directly to them without adopting a restrictive interpretation of s.135A of the National Health Act;

speech.para: Response

The Government notes this recommendation. A protocol will be prepared by the Department of Health and Family Services, in consultation with the NPHAC and the Privacy Commissioner which sets out the procedure for a recipient to access information about their treatment.
Context

When recipients make initial contact with the Department, they receive information about their treatment through a General Practitioner nominated by the recipient, to ensure that the recipient is correctly identified and that there is support immediately available to the recipient when they are informed of the increased risk of CJD and any related issues.

para.inline: (e) Index to Allars Report—That an index to the Allars Report be prepared and made readily accessible for all recipients and other interested parties;

speech.para: Response

The Government notes this recommendation and that an index to the Allars Report was prepared following the release of the Allars Report. The next edition of the HPH newsletter will include a statement that this index is available and indicate how copies can be obtained.

para.inline: (f) NPHAC—Ensure that NPHAC's processes and procedures are sufficiently open and flexible to enable it to receive views and opinions from all members of the recipient community on issues under consideration by the Council; and that all recipients are kept informed of decisions taken by NPHAC and their outcome.

speech.para: Response

The Government accepts this recommendation. The next edition of the HPH newsletter will include a re-statement of the role of the NPHAC and of the mechanisms available to the hormone recipient community to have input in to the Council's activities.
Context

The NPHAC was established following the Allars Inquiry, to provide advice to the Minister on issues of national significance to the hormone recipient community. The procedures available for recipients to bring issues to the attention of the NPHAC were set out in two editions of the HPH newsletter . Recipients can raise issues with their CJD Support Group Co-ordinator, the National Co-ordinator of the CJD Support Group Network Inc., or to write directly to the NPHAC. Information about the discussions and decisions of the NPHAC is contained in the HPH newsletter following a meeting of the NPHAC.

para.inline: (g) Statement on Human Experimentation—That the review of the Statement on Human Experimentation which is not due to be finalised until late 1998 be expedited. To ensure that this review is not delayed, the Committee urges the Minister to finalise the appointment of members of the AHEC as soon as possible;

speech.para: Response
The Government notes this recommendation. The Chair of the NHMRC has advised the Department of Health and Family Services of progress with this Review.
Context

The Australian Health Ethics Committee (AHEC) is a principal committee of the NHMRC. The first round of consultation on the review of the Statement on Human Experimentation is complete and submissions will be considered at the next meeting of AHEC.

para.inline: (h) Amendment of s.135A of the National Health Act—That s.135A of the National Health Act be amended to ensure that personal information can be disclosed directly to the people about whom the information relates (such as in the case of people who received hormone treatment) and that the Attorney-General's Department broader review of existing secrecy provisions, which includes s135A, be expedited; and

speech.para: Response

The Government notes that the Attorney-General's Department is undertaking a broad review of existing secrecy provisions, which includes consideration of s.135A of the National Health Act 1953 . The Government will consider the question of amendment of s.135A in light of the outcome of this review.
Context

Section 135A of the National Health Act 1953 requires that personal information cannot be released to a third party without the consent of the individual, or where the delegate of the Minister deems it to be in the public interest. The Department must be satisfied as to the identity of the person seeking personal information. An ongoing review of such provisions is taking place within the Attorney-General's Department.

para.inline: (i) Amendment of s.100 of the National Health Act—That the ALRC review which includes consideration of the Allars recommendation to repeal and replace s.100 by a provision which specifies clearly the circumstances where by reason of physical and similar factors associated with the distribution of a pharmaceutical benefit `special arrangements' are appropriate, be expedited.

speech.para: Response

The Government notes this recommendation. A review of previous applications of section 100 will be conducted to ensure such use has been consistent with the purpose of that provision. The Government will consider the need for amendment to section 100 in light of this review.
Context

Section 100 of the National Health Act 1953 allows for special arrangements for providing pharmaceutical benefits to people living in isolated areas or who are receiving medical treatment such that pharmaceutical benefits cannot be conveniently or efficiently supplied in accordance with the general provisions of the pharmaceutical benefit scheme.

para.inline: Recommendation 3. That should legal action proceed, the documentation requested from the Commonwealth through a discovery or further and better discovery process be complied with in a more expeditious manner than has been the case to date. In complying with such discovery processes the Commonwealth should refrain from adopting a restrictive interpretation of s135A of the National Health Act.

speech.para: Response
The Government accepts that discovery in litigation should be undertaken by the Commonwealth expeditiously and without taking an unduly restrictive approach to secrecy provisions.

The Government notes that arrangements have been agreed between the solicitors acting for the parties as to how the further discovery would proceed. These agreed arrangements have been followed by the Commonwealth.

The Government notes the Committee's recommendation regarding the interpretation of s.135A of the National Health Act 1953 but does not agree that the Commonwealth in ensuring that s.135A has been complied with, has adopted a restrictive interpretation of the section. The Commonwealth's interpretation and application of s.135A permitted hormone recipients to have access to their own medical information once the identity of the hormone recipient had been verified. The Commonwealth did not rely on s.135A as a means of preventing disclosure of relevant material in discovery.
The Government also notes that the Attorney-General's Department is currently undertaking a review of secrecy provisions, including s.135A.

para.inline: Recommendation 4. That the process whereby a Department, being a defendant in a legal action taken against the Commonwealth, is placed in the situation of advising on the release (or refusal) of documents to a plaintiff—yet having full access to all documents themselves—is reviewed, so that procedures may be implemented to ensure that the process is transparent and that any conflict of interest, perceived or otherwise, is avoided.

speech.para: Response

In the Government's view, the requirements of litigation, which apply to all litigants, render it impossible to avoid the situation to which this recommendation relates. However, the Government accepts that in special circumstances, and where practicable, it may be appropriate to take steps to reduce concerns regarding transparency or objectivity.
Context

Discovery is a process whereby parties to court proceedings identify and disclose to each other all their own documents which are relevant to the issues in the proceedings. This of its very nature requires a party to have full access to that party's own documents to determine whether a document is discoverable.

Once documents have been identified as relevant, a party may resist disclosure of the contents of a document on several grounds. These grounds include a statutory secrecy provision, public interest immunity (privilege) or legal professional privilege. Once again, it is necessary for a party to have full access to documents in order to determine whether a ground to resist production exists. Even where the party is legally represented, the party needs to have a knowledge of the material relating to the case, in order to be able to provide proper instructions to the legal representative.

Even if disclosure of relevant documentation is resisted, the existence of such documentation must be disclosed on discovery. Therefore, the discovery process prevents concealment of the existence of relevant documentation by a party in reliance on a secrecy provision. Overall, in relation to discovery, the Commonwealth is in no better position than a non-Commonwealth party to proceedings.

The Government acknowledges that adoption of normal practice may result in perceptions of unfairness in special circumstances, such as where relevant documents held by a department include the results of a public inquiry involving both parties to the litigation. In order to avoid that perception, for the purposes of the CJD litigation, within the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) the discovery of the documents of the Allars Inquiry was handled separately from the defence of the action. The discovery work was performed by a separate legal team ('the AGS Discovery team'). In deciding whether or not to recommend that documents be discovered in the Victorian proceedings, the AGS Discovery Team did not consult with AGS staff handling the defence of the litigation ('the AGS Litigation Team'). The AGS Discovery Team engaged separate counsel to advise on discovery issues relating to the documents of the Inquiry. The AGS Discovery Team did not at any stage work on the preparation of the defence of the litigation. Whenever Allars Inquiry documents were released to Rennick Briggs, the solicitors acting for the plaintiffs in the Victorian proceedings, copies were provided to the AGS litigation team, but not before. In the NSW proceedings Macedone Christie Willis, the solicitors acting for the plaintiffs, have agreed that the AGS Litigation and Discovery teams may confer about the relevance of documents for the purpose of discovery.

In summary, the discovery process of its very nature requires a party to have full access to all that party's documents. Generally, a Commonwealth Department which is required to also comply with a secrecy provision such as s.135A should be placed in no different position to a non-Commonwealth litigant reviewing its documents to determine whether documents are relevant to the proceedings and, if so, whether disclosure should be resisted.

para.inline: Recommendation 5. That the settlement offer should not preclude a plaintiff making any future claim in relation to:
(a) other physical illnesses contracted by recipients which may be related to long term side effects of HPH treatment; and
(b) liability should the transmission of CJD, or other illnesses relating to HPH treatment, to immediate family be proven.

speech.para: Response

The Government notes this recommendation and also that the settlement offer does not preclude a plaintiff making any future claim in relation to physical illnesses contracted by recipients which may be related to long term side effects of pituitary hormone treatment. The settlement offer does not preclude a plaintiff making a future claim that they have contracted CJD, or other illnesses relating to pituitary hormone treatment, as a result of being an immediate family member of a hormone recipient.

para.inline: Recommendation 6. That, without conceding the likelihood or otherwise of a legal action on psychiatric stress succeeding, in addition to the current settlement offer, the Commonwealth:

(a) make an allocation of funds to the existing Trust Account and that its purpose be widened. The amount of additional funding should, as a minimum, be equivalent to the cost of the potential litigation;

(b) widen the purpose of the Trust Account to permit one-off payments to be made to recipients who provide evidence that they have suffered psychiatric injury as a result of treatment under the AHPHP. This payment be made on a sliding scale relating to the level of psychiatric injury suffered by the recipient. This payment would be regarded as a form of ex-gratia payment and would not constitute any precedent for similar action;
(c) consider extending this offer of payment to include recipients who have suffered psychological stress or significant life disturbance; and

(d) appoint an independent governing Board to authorise payments from the Trust to replace authorisation by the delegate of the Minister. The Board would be responsible for receiving and assessing applications for recompense.

speech.para: Response

An amount of up to a further three million dollars will be allocated to the Pituitary Hormones Trust Account to allow for payments to be made to recipients who can demonstrate that, prior to 1 January 1998, they have, or have suffered, a recognised psychiatric injury due to the recipient having been informed that they are at a greater risk of contracting Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease.

These funds will be made available in two separate instalments. The first instalment of $1.5 million will be provided in 1998-99, with a second instalment of up to $1.5 million in 1999-2000 after consideration has been given to the position of the Pituitary Hormones Trust Account and any new litigation costs, particularly the costs to the Commonwealth of having to defend such litigation, as a result of hormone recipients having chosen to litigate rather than pursue payments from the Pituitary Hormones Trust Account.

In making payments, priority will be given to those hormone recipients who have the most serious psychiatric injury. The Pituitary Hormones Trust Account Management and Administration Guidelines will be amended to provide a framework within which such payments can be made.

The Government has also considered extending payments from the Pituitary Hormone Trust Account to recipients who have suffered psychological stress or significant life disturbance, and has decided not to extend payments in this way.

The Government will appoint an independent Board to authorise payments from the Pituitary Hormones Trust Account. Payments will only be made to those hormone recipients who can demonstrate they have a recognised psychiatric injury due to the recipient having been informed that they are at a greater risk of contracting Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease.

para.inline: Recommendation 7. That recipients who have already accepted the settlement offer would also be eligible for the additional offer as outlined in Recommendation 6, providing they have evidence of psychiatric injury, psychological stress or significant life disturbance.

speech.para: See Recommendation 6.

para.inline: Recommendation 8. That unapproved recipients, who are formally identified and accepted through the process outlined in Recommendations 2 & 14, be eligible for the additional settlement arrangements already offered to recipients as well as those outlined in Recommendations 6 & 15.

speech.para: Response
The Government agrees to adopt this recommendation.

para.inline: Recommendation 9. The Commonwealth formally acknowledge:
(a) the deficiencies in the operation and oversight of the AHPHP;
(b) the experimental nature of aspects of the treatment under the Program; and
(c) the anxiety and stress that has been caused to hormone recipients.

speech.para: Response

(a) The previous Government received a report from Professor Allars in June 1994. In the Report of the Inquiry into the use of Pituitary Derived Hormones in Australia and Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, Associate Professor Allars reported a number of concerns about the operation of the AHPHP and the decisions taken by various advisory committees and departmental officers at the time.
The Commonwealth formally acknowledges that there were some deficiencies in the operation and oversight of the Australian Human Pituitary Hormone Program.
In order to ensure the highest standard in future programs the Commonwealth has adopted most of the recommendations made by Professor Allars.

The Commonwealth acknowledges that it is a great tragedy that some of the people who were treated under the AHPHP have now died as a result of CJD and that a group of Australians now live with the uncertainty of being at risk of contracting CJD. It is deeply regrettable that this tragedy has occurred.

(b) The Government does not acknowledge that treatment administered under the AHPHP was experimental. When hormone products were first issued in 1967 for the treatment of patients approved under the AHPHP, hormone treatment had been in operation overseas since 1958 and in Australia since 1963.

It is acknowledged that a small number of recipients received hormone in a small number of research studies which were undertaken under the AHPHP, some of which were referred to by the Senate Community Affairs References Committee.
(c) The Government acknowledges that a number of recipients have suffered distress and anxiety and it expresses its sympathy to those recipients who have been affected.
Context

In her Report of the Inquiry into the use of Pituitary Derived Hormones in Australia and Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, Associate Professor Allars reported a number of concerns about the operation of the AHPHP and the decisions taken by various advisory committees and departmental officers at the time.

para.inline: Recommendation 10. That the current eligibility guidelines for the provision of legal aid be revised to ensure that cases, particularly test cases, involving issues of public interest such as those raised in APQ's case be eligible to receive legal aid assistance in the future.

speech.para: Response
The Government does not accept this recommendation.
Context

The principle which underpins the legal aid system in Australia is one of matching priorities to available funds. Legal aid in Australia is not an entitlement based system. Accordingly, each case must be considered not only from the perspective of its merits but also in relation to whether funds are available.

para.inline: Recommendation 11. That, in future, the determination of legal aid applications should be made in accordance with the guidelines operating at the time the application was submitted. Thus, any variations to eligibility criteria would only apply to applications submitted after such variations had been introduced.

speech.para: Response
The Government does not accept this recommendation.
Context
Assistance under the guidelines for legal aid must be considered in light of available funds at any particular point in time.

para.inline: Recommendation 12. That the Department review all possible tracing methods in an attempt to identify the remaining 190 or so untraced approved recipients.

speech.para: Response
See response to recommendation 2(c) above.

para.inline: Recommendation 13. That the coding system being developed for lists of recipients distributed to Blood Banks and organ and tissue agencies be completed as a matter of priority.

speech.para: Response

The Government notes this recommendation and that the list of names of recipients has now been encoded and provided to the National Centre in HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research, for a preliminary trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the coded system. This matter is being progressed as a matter of priority.
Context

A list of the names of hormone recipients has been provided to blood, organ and tissue donation agencies to ensure that people at an increased risk of CJD (through hormone treatment) are not included in donation programs. Concerns were raised by some recipients that this was an invasion of their privacy. The NPHAC agreed with the need for this list to be made available and that any copies of the list distributed in the future should be in a `coded' form to protect the privacy of recipients as far as possible.

para.inline: Recommendation 14. That the Department allocate resources to tracing unapproved recipients of human-derived pituitary hormones.

speech.para: Response

The Government notes this recommendation and that the Department of Health and Family Services is currently investigating strategies to identify unapproved recipients of the hormone and to trace the remaining recipients.
Context

Information about unapproved recipients is only available in the records of doctors who were providing treatment under the AHPHP. The Department will be required to contact each surviving treating doctor requesting their further assistance in identifying unapproved recipients.

para.inline: Recommendation 15. That once it is established that a person did receive hPG or hGH from the AHPHP, the recipient's status should be of no difference to that of approved recipients. In the event of a dispute between the Department and a person who claims to have received human pituitary derived hormone, the matter should be referred to an independent arbiter for resolution.

speech.para: Response

The Government accepts this recommendation. No distinction is made between those recipients who were approved and those who were not approved for treatment by HPAC. An independent arbiter for any cases of dispute will be appointed to determine whether or not a recipient has received human pituitary derived hormones.
Context
See recommendation 8.

para.inline: Recommendation 16. That the Department put in place protocols to ensure sympathetic early intervention so that information and assistance is provided to a recipient suspected to have contracted CJD as soon as the recipient's condition becomes known, rather than await official confirmation.

speech.para: Response

The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that a procedure for responding to possible further cases of CJD in hormone recipients is in place and was implemented in relation to the recent possible case of CJD.
Context

When the possible fifth case of CJD in a hormone recipient was recognised in 1995, a protocol was prepared setting out the procedure for responding to future possible cases of CJD in a hormone recipient. This procedure was subsequently refined with the establishment of the Pituitary Hormones Trust Account and the availability of funds for medical and other care costs.

para.inline: Recommendation 17. That the Department inform the recipient community of the steps to be taken to make an application to the Department for assistance, including the persons to be contacted and the information required, in the event that it is suspected of that a person has contracted CJD.

speech.para: Response
The Government accepts this recommendation. This information will be included in the next edition of the HPH newsletter .
Context
See Recommendation 16.

para.inline: 18. That, in view of the availability of further information (much of which is conflicting in its nature) which may not have been considered by the Allars Inquiry, Professor Margaret Allars be invited to review, with the necessary independent scientific advice, this further information on scientific matters concerning the AHPHP which has become available since the Allars Inquiry reported. If Professor Allars in unavailable, another suitable qualified person be invited to undertake the review.

speech.para: Response

Associate Professor Allars has been asked to review the `further information on scientific matters concerning the AHPHP' that was submitted in camera to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee Inquiry and determine whether this information was available at the time that she conducted the Inquiry into the Use of Pituitary Derived Hormones in Australia and Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease .

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Senate Community Affairs References Committee conducted its CJD inquiry last July and August. It was a difficult inquiry for all senators from all parties to participate in because of the death of five individuals in recent years who had contracted CJD. The committee was made up of representatives of the Labor Party, government senators, a representative of the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine.

The inquiry was conducted in a relatively constructive manner over two days in Canberra. A large number of witnesses came forward to give evidence of their experience and participation in the CJD program from the late 1960s until it was curtailed somewhere around about 1985. Those witnesses were under great stress. They expressed great feeling and great emotion to those senators who participated. Many of the witnesses saw the Senate inquiry as a forum in which they could seek some form of justice for themselves or their families who had contracted the disease and who had suffered some horrible consequences. CJD applies only to infertile females who receive the treatment or to persons of short stature who take the growth hormone.

The report by the Community Affairs References Committee was brought down, from memory, last September or October. There were 32 recommendations in total in 18 paragraphs, one or two of which had multiple recommendations. After reviewing the government's response to the recommendations of the Community Affairs References Committee, I am pleased to note that the government has accepted all of the recommendations bar three. So some 28 or 29 of the committee's recommendations have been accepted by the government, as outlined in the document that has been incorporated in Hansard today.

The key recommendations can be conveniently subdivided into five areas: firstly, psychiatric injury; secondly, communications guidelines; thirdly, administrative procedures and processes within the relevant department; fourthly, the processes that individuals have to undergo to qualify for legal aid funding; and, fifthly, further review by Professor Allars.

The key recommendation may be found in paragraphs 6(a) to (d) of the Senate committee report, and the government has accepted that in total. The government has determined to allocate an additional $3 million in two instalments of $1.5 million each to be paid into the pituitary hormone trust account. Payment will be made on a sliding scale to those persons who are suffering what the government calls recognised psychiatric injury.

Another committee recommendation was that the government consider extending psychiatric injury to those persons who suffer psychological stress or significant life disturbance. The committee recognised that the latter two categories were qualitatively different from those persons who suffered from psychiatric injury. I have to acknowledge here that the government, in its response, indeed accepted our recommendation to consider extending the claimants to persons who are suffering from psychological stress or signifi cant life disturbance but in its wisdom, having considered that recommendation, has rejected it.

The final worthwhile aspect of (d) is that an independent board will receive applications for recompense and make the appropriate determination to accept or reject. That will no longer be a process conducted by delegated authority from the minister's office.

The second most important recommendation from my perspective is recommendation 18, that Professor Allars conduct a further review of the additional scientific information provided to the committee. A lot of that information was, as one would assume, quite technical, some of it narrowly focused, a lot of it open to conflicting interpretations and a lot of it buried in the mists of time. I cannot comment for other senators, but I had difficulty in coming to terms with some of that technical information. In those circumstances, we recommended that Professor Allars, having had some considerable expertise in this area, be requested to further review that material.

I am informed by an officer of the minister's department that they have accepted that recommendation and that the additional scientific information that was provided to the committee in camera has been forwarded to Dr Allars, who is on some sort of temporary relocation in the United Kingdom, and she is in the process of reviewing that additional information. I look forward to receiving her report in due course to test whether the allegations that were raised in the committee process as to the damage that was done and the cause thereof have any substance.

In summary, it was quite a difficult inquiry. All senators who participated did so in a most constructive manner and, as a consequence, a unanimous set of recommendations went to the government last September or October. The government has, in its wisdom, accepted nearly all of those recommendations and rejected two or three that go to policy matters regarding legal aid funding. While we do not agree with the government's decision, we understand its reasoning. But I should stress that the government has accepted the key recommendations.

I am particularly pleased to note that an additional $3 million has been allocated to the relevant trust account for those persons who suffer psychiatric damage to draw upon in due course. I note, finally, that the government has accepted and is in the process of implementing changes to administrative guidelines within the relevant department and communications guidelines for those persons who suffer from CJD and their families.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I support Senator Bishop's remarks about the difficulty experienced in coming to terms with this particularly difficult subject. The Senate Community Affairs References Committee raised in its report on the CJD settlement offer a number of issues in relation to the Australian human pituitary hormone program, the response to the cessation of this program, the litigation and the settlement offer made by the Commonwealth.

speech.para: The government agrees wholeheartedly with the committee's general view that this is a tragic episode for all involved and that support must be given to those affected. The government acknowledges that there were some deficiencies in the operation and oversight of this hormone program and a small number of recipients have suffered distress and anxiety, which is deeply regretted. As a former Chairman of the Community Affairs References Committee, I recall this was something that we grappled with, and former Senator John Coulter had a particular interest in establishing an inquiry.

It should be noted that the establishment of this inquiry represented rather a sea change by the opposition. In 1995, when in government, those opposite did not agree to a proposal by the Australian Democrats that there should be a Senate committee inquiry into CJD issues. The principal grounds for this refusal, which we as the then opposition agreed with, were that there had recently been a comprehensive public inquiry by Professor Margaret Allars into the complex matters surrounding the human growth hormone program and that it was very questionable that a Senate committee would throw any new light on these issues.

It was also likely that there were some people who would want to selectively revisit past events and use the opportunity afforded by the privilege of the parliament to make unnecessary and unsubstantiated statements about individuals and organisations, most notably CSL in the period when it was a Commonwealth government entity and when the issues relating to unconventional slow viral infections transmitted by hormones from collected pituitary glands were not understood as they are now.

I recall that it was Professor Gajdusek who won the Nobel Prize for his work on slow viral transmission of disease that led to the recognition of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. It is worth recalling what the Minister representing the Minister for Health said in this chamber in 1995, when rejecting a parliamentary inquiry:

. . . a retrospective judgement is very easy to make but it does not necessarily give us more truth or more accuracy. Particularly when you have diseases with such long lead times as CJD or HIV, I think historical backing up is particularly fraught.
We agreed with the government of the day on that when we were in opposition. I agreed with Senator Crowley on that occasion, and I and the government still do.

However, the perspective of those opposite has obviously changed since they lost the election two years ago. That said, it is very important to stress—as indeed both the then government and the opposition did in 1995—that CSL, a listed company, meets, as all other pharmaceutical companies are required to do, very high manufacturing standards. CSL holds a licence to manufacture therapeutic goods issued under the regulations of the Therapeutic Goods Act.

In its preparation of blood plasma products, vaccines and other biological products CSL is subject to rigorous audit by the Therapeutic Goods Authority and been found since the regulations came into effect in 1991 to comply fully with the TGA code of good manufacturing practice. CSL is an Australian success story. It is also essential that we remember that many Australians have derived enormous benefit over many years from the products manufactured by CSL, which have enabled them to enjoy a better quality of life.

Turning to the committee's report, the government accepts the great majority of the recommendations made in it. The government has decided to allocate up to a further $3 million to the human pituitary hormones trust account to provide for one-off payments to be made to any hormone recipients who can show that they have a psychiatric injury caused by their being told they are at a greater risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

All hormone recipients who have received human pituitary derived hormone made by CSL on behalf of the Australian human pituitary hormone program and who have suffered a recognised psychiatric injury, regardless of whether they have sued the Commonwealth or whether their treatment was approved or unapproved by the Australian human pituitary hormone program, are eligible to apply for a one-off payment from these funds.

The government will also establish an independent board to authorise payments from the trust account for a recognised psychiatric injury and to consider applications from hormone recipients. In this way the government will ensure that the decisions regarding such payments are made by an independent group of experts.

The government decided to allocate up to $3 million in line with the committee's recommendation 6(a) that the amount, as a minimum, be equivalent to the cost of potential litigation. In fact, the estimates received by the government for continuing the litigation were below this amount, but we have decided to make the greater amount available.

These funds will be available in two separate instalments. The first instalment of $1½ million will be put into the trust account straight away. The independent trust account board will then make a determination on the payments to recipients who make an application. The second instalment of up to a further $1½ million will be made in the 1999-2000 financial year.

These funds will be allocated after consideration has been given to the position of the trust account and of any new litigation costs that are borne by the Commonwealth. This particularly refers to any costs the Commonwealth has to incur in having to defend such litigation where a recipient has chosen to litigate rather than seek funds through the trust account mechanism that is being established. I understand that the recent APQ settlement offer remains open to all the recipients who are still litigating and that, if they accept the settlement, they will still be eligible to seek money from the trust account.

The government believes that this process will provide those suffering from a recognised psychiatric injury with additional financial assistance. The government also gave serious consideration to the recommendation that the trust account be extended to include—as the committee recommended in recommendation 6(c)—recipients who have suffered psychological stress or significant life disturbance.

After serious consideration of this issue, the government has concluded that the counselling support services that are already operating provide the most appropriate means of support to those who may be suffering in this way. Any recipient or member of a recipient's family can receive counselling in accordance with the guidelines in place from a counsellor approved by the expert counselling panel and the government will pay the bills directly.

In relation to the further information which the Senate inquiry identified as possibly not having been seen by Professor Allars during her independent Inquiry, I can inform the Senate that Professor Allars is currently examining these documents and the government is awaiting her report.

The government notes that, in addition to the comments made in the report in relation to the Commonwealth's activities following the end of the program, the committee concluded that, firstly, legal aid was not unfairly denied to APQ and, secondly, that the settlement offer was fair and adequate.

The government earnestly hopes that this further assistance to recipients will help to bring this difficult and tragic situation to something of a conclusion by providing support and acknowledging the suffering being experienced.
I commend the government's response to the report on the CJD settlement offer to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —Of all the committee hearings I have been a part of in my time in this chamber I would have to say that this was really the most depressing and in many ways very stressful for all members of the committee.

speech.para: I can imagine what it must be like for those recipients in this program and their families who have battled with this for years, some of them—as Senator Bishop said—since the sixties and seventies, and who now live with that cloud still hanging over them. For us this is over; for them it is certainly not over.

I wish to acknowledge in particular the work of my colleague the former Senator John Coulter and his efforts over many years to get what he considered to be justice, and also to Senator Brian Harradine another activist in this area who has worked long and hard with the individual families, particularly those families who have stood up and kept asking that the government listen to them.

On my first reading of this response I was rather disappointed, particularly with the refusal to extend payments to those who have suffered psychological stress or significant life disturbance. This was a deliberate decision of the committee. We listened to many stories from individuals about the stresses that they feel, the persecution they have come up against, the historic problems both they and their families have come up against and the problems they have had to face even in the workplace. For them now to have to go through the process of actually acknowledging that they really do have a psychiatric injury is in many cases another very daunting exercise. That is the only way that they are going to be able to tap into the extra money.

However, I am pleased that the government has acknowledged in dollar terms that there is still some recompense to go. On going back through all of this response I can see there are certainly quite a few positives in it. I must congratulate the committee as a whole. The fact is that this was a unanimous report of all members who sat on the committee. I guess, in a way, this is the minimal response we could have accepted from the government because all parties, all members of that committee, felt very strongly about these recommendations. There was no dissent. I also must congratulate the staff on the committee for whom also this was a very intense experience and one where, as usual, they worked very hard.

Just to look at a couple of the positives: of the many recommendations that have been accepted, in particular I welcome the review of the National Pituitary Hormone Advisory Council's decision not to proceed with the epidemiological study. This will enable the council to obtain independent expert advice on the issue. I am also pleased to see the government has accepted recommendations relating to the rights of hormone recipients and their families to services and, as Senator Herron has gone through, a number of those issues were brought up time and time again during the committee process. It is vital that people affected by CJD be aware of their entitlements—and it was evident that all of them certainly were not.

I look forward to receiving further information from government on the progress of the review and the statement on human experimentation currently being undertaken by the Australian Health Ethics Committee. I also welcome the development of a protocol setting out the procedures for a recipient to access information about their treatment. I welcome the clarification in this document that a settlement offer does not preclude a plaintiff from making a future claim in relation to physical illness that might be contracted by recipients and which could be related to the long-term side effects of hormone treatment.

The report also states that the settlement offer does not preclude a plaintiff making a future claim that they have contracted CJD or other illnesses relating to program treatment as a result of being an immediate family member of a recipient. On balance, it is a minimal response but a good one and I hope that for the recipients and for their families this is another small step on their path to finding justice and getting an acknowledgment from government that they have a major ongoing and very stressful experience to get through. I will be talking to them in the coming weeks and I hope that they do find this response by government positive.

talk.start.para: —I would like to reiterate what has been said in the chamber. This was a cooperative effort and it showed how the Senate can work. The Senate's functions include the protection of a person's individual rights and this was an example whereby experimental action was taken to overcome an infertility or small stature problem without, I believe, the prudence which should have accompanied those decisions. I do congratulate Senator Bishop on the way that he chaired the inquiry and all of those members of the committee, including the previous speaker, Senator Lees. I feel, as she does, that because the recommendations were a unanimous decision of the committee they carried a fair bit of weight.

speech.para: The government's response, however, whilst generally acceptable—and I acknowledge it to be generally acceptable—is in some respects questionable. I will give you a clear example. Recommendation 9 the committee made was that the Commonwealth formally acknowledge (a), (b) and (c), where (b) is `the experimental nature of aspects of the treatment under the Program'. The response by the government does not acknowledge the experimental nature, even though the chief medical officer, Tony Adams, told the committee that it was experimental. We had substantial information that led us to suggest that the Commonwealth should acknowledge the experimental nature of aspects of the treatment under the program.

It is disappointing because what we want to emerge out of this is not only justice and compassion for those that suffered this disease as the result of the experimental nature of the program, but also for the Commonwealth department and others to learn the message. Too often in this area of reproductive technology, prudence just goes out the window. In this case, the fact is that the infertile women and persons of small stature had been treated as guinea pigs. That should not occur again.
There are a number of other matters to which I wish to advert, but I do not have time to do so now, so in a moment I will seek leave to continue my remarks later. Recommendation 3 states:

That should legal action proceed, the documentation requested from the Commonwealth through a discovery or further and better discovery process be complied with in a more expeditious manner than has been the case to date. In complying with such discovery processes the Commonwealth should refrain from adopting a restrictive interpretation of s135A of the National Health Act.
The government's response says:
The Government accepts that discovery in litigation should be undertaken by the Commonwealth expeditiously and without taking an unduly restrictive approach to secrecy provisions.
The Government notes that arrangements have been agreed between the solicitors acting for the parties . . . These agreed arrangements have been followed by the Commonwealth.

The Government notes the Committee's recommendation regarding the interpretation of s.135A of the National Health Act 1953 but does not agree that the Commonwealth in ensuring that s.135A has been complied with, has adopted a restrictive interpretation of the section.

Frankly, that is a disappointing response to our recommendations. Whether or not CJD litigation continues, it is possible that the Commonwealth will continue with its restrictive interpretation to frustrate discovery and/or procedural processes when litigation has been commenced against it. I believe that the government's rejection of the committee's findings in this respect is particularly strange, given the court's interpretation of the provision and similar secrecy provisions. I hope that this is not the attitude that is going to be adopted by the Commonwealth department of health in respect of this or other matters.

There were quite a number of people who were very helpful to the committee. Those people included Frank Peters and Karen Weeks. It is a bit invidious naming just two because there are quite a number of others. I feel it would be more appropriate for me to seek leave to continue my remarks now so that we can return to this matter more fully in due course.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee entitled A class act: inquiry into the status of the teaching profession , together with submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is very important indeed. It is called A class act and reports on the status of the teaching profession. As our report says, it really gives a window into teaching in Australia at the end of the twentieth century. I believe the report will serve the needs of lots of people who have an interest in education, teaching and the state of our schools. Indeed, it follows very well our previous reports, particularly on the private funding of public schools.

I note with interest that my colleagues have just finished discussing a government response to a Senate report. I would be very pleased to be able to say that, in the area of education, the government had responded to any of our reports. But it is a sad fact that our committee, since we have been writing reports with the change of government, has not had any government response. We have written a report on early childhood education called Childhood matters; we have written a report on adult education called Beyond Cinderella; and we have written a report on the private funding of public schools. To this point, even though some of those reports have been outstanding for 21 months, contrary to the convention of responding within three months, we have heard not a word from the government on any of those reports. That is very disappointing for so many people who put such an effort into coming forward and making submissions, particularly in the area of education. It is a major concern for the community, and this report only confirms that.

I would like to take the opportunity to thank those involved with the preparation of the report, in particular the secretariat principally responsible for the report—Brenton Holmes and Jan Connaughton. They were involved in the committee until very recently; they have now moved to other positions in the Senate. I also thank Jan Willis and in particular Mary Lindsay who at very short notice was asked to come in and assist the committee in preparing this report. Mary had not been present at any of the public hearings, and she had to read her way through all the submissions—well over 308 submissions—and the evidence and transcripts from all the public hearings, which were extensive. So I place on record my appreciation for the work that they have done.

One of the things that struck the committee very powerfully was the unanimity of views of all the people who put forward submissions. Everybody is of the view that there is a very significant challenge—from a crisis to major problems confronting the status of teachers and teaching in this country.

The second thing that I think is important is the unanimity of view between private and public schools. With regard to complaints against public schools, there was no way in which the private schools making submissions to this committee would be caught up with, or in any way sucked into, that old debate. They made it clear that the best thing for the private schools in this country is a strong and well funded and well appreciated public sector—that is, it is best for education if both travel together, and in no way is there any benefit to education to open the old sectarian debate between public and private schooling.

Most importantly, it was agreed by so many witnesses before the committee that the status of teaching and the status of education is not helped by governments blaming teachers for anything and everything connected to schools that may go wrong. It is one thing indeed to challenge teachers about the status of literacy of our school children, even though there has been considerable debate—and I will not canvass it here, except to say that I do not think it was accurately represented by the federal minister, Dr Kemp—but it is another thing altogether to be saying that it is the schools that are responsible for unemployment. Teachers, indeed, began to feel that they were wearing responsibility for just about everything that could go wrong in our society, and that certainly does not make them feel confident or best able to provide optimal education for our children.

Neither is education in our country assisted by unseemly brawling between Commonwealth and state ministers about just whose responsibility it is for funding of our schools, and so on. We have seen the same kind of debate happening between the Commonwealth and states on the question of health. We have also seen it earlier on between the Commonwealth and the state ministers regarding funding for education in our schools. Governments brawling over funding for education, education ministers brawling between themselves about who is responsible for the cutbacks in funding for education, governments blaming teachers and teaching all send a very strong message to teachers and our schools that this is not an area that is highly prized; this is not an area that is highly regarded by government.

In days past, I thought it was the responsibility of governments in large part certainly to be seen as advocates for their area of responsibility. Of recent times, we seem to have had quite a change. The first thing that ministers do is offload some responsibility in their own areas of responsibility—in this case schools. That does nothing to persuade those teachers or the community that education is an invaluable and excellent contribution.

Our report also concludes that there is no way in which you can have a sophisticated, civilised and decent society without you have quality education; and there is no way you can have quality education without you have quality teaching. That is, the status of teachers and teaching is critical to good educational outcomes and the optimal way in which our society views itself and tackles challenges confronting it. If we want the best for our children, if we want the best for our families, then we certainly need to back up a good education system with good teaching.

We have heard these complaints before and it is interesting to find them once again being raised before this committee—that is, the downgrading or the challenging of teachers. There are the increasing demands being put on them. For example, there is the crowded curriculum. More and more is being asked of teachers, and very few things drop off that curriculum.

We also have heard at length about the social work dimension of teaching. Many families now regard their children's teachers as the first port of call when facing difficulties within their own lives or within their own community. We also have heard of teachers, particularly principals—as highlighted very well in our previous report—who spend some of their professional teaching time in fundraising to assist their school to get the necessary funding to go on providing the salaries and support for teaching in that school.

Also, of course, we have heard many a time of the challenge for our schools and our teachers with the introduction of new technology, particularly computers, in our schools. They are just some of the areas that have been highlighted so well in submissions before this inquiry.

Our principal recommendation is that it is time to put beyond doubt the fact that teaching is a profession. It is not worth our arguing any more whether or not it is a profession; it is accepted, and it must be accepted, that it is a profession. Our first and principal recommendation therefore requires that, in recognition of that, there be the establishment of a national professional teaching standards and registration body to have the responsibility, authority and resources to develop and maintain standards of professional practice.

Listed in our recommendation are a number of critical areas of responsibility: standards of professional practice, certification for entry into the profession, recognition of advanced standards, accreditation of programs for initial teacher training, priority for national professional development programs, complaints about professional incompetence, register of teachers across the nation, and promoting the value of teaching in the general community. Many of the other recommendations highlight and go to the points that I have raised in terms of the challenges to teaching.

We have a dissenting report, so this is not a unanimous report. It is disappointing to me in a way that we do have a difference of opinion here. But, if you read the dissenting report, you will find there is very little difference indeed. Indeed, at one hearing, when we were considering the recommendations, there was an understanding that there would be a unanimous recommendation. But the government members have introduced a dissenting report, and they have changed just a word here or there.

We have recommended that there be a national professional teaching standards and registration body; in particular, we say it should be built on what each state says. The dissenting report says that teaching belongs in the states, and so that is where the principal focus should come from. But anybody reading this report should look at the dissenting report and see that the recommendations are almost word for word; the difference lies just in who they ask to take responsibility for that.

I commend this excellent report to the Senate, and I urge the government to take seriously the convention of responding to Senate reports. We have had no response to any of our reports. Teaching, education in this country deserves that the government do the decent thing and let us know what they think of the recommendations in this report and all the previous reports from our committee.

talk.start.para: —I speak to the motion and commend the report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Committee to the Senate. The central proposition of the committee's inquiry is that high quality teaching stands central to the provision of high quality education systems; and that critical to the success of our educational experience is, of course, high quality teaching experience.

speech.para: This report demonstrates that across this country there is a profound sense of malaise amongst the nation's 250,000 teachers. This malaise is not confined to the public sector; it is also being experienced very widely within the private sector. This is a result of the very complex changes that are occurring within society which are reflected in our schooling systems. It is a product of the changes that are occurring within curriculum development and curriculum delivery in terms of the technology that is available for teaching, and it is a reflection of the broader social changes which are occurring within society at large.

These changes are producing radically new expectations of what should be provided in our educational institutions. They are often presented as an overlay against the traditional view of what educational experiences should involve. In a sense there is a demand by society and by a range of authorities that teachers and schools do more and do it differently. At the same time there is a demand that they do it the same and that they produce the outcomes that people have expected over time. These are often contradictory demands which are supposed to be met by our schools and by our teachers at a time when there are fewer resources available and being provided by governments to meet those demands.

These are demands that require new levels of skill, of time and of increasing demands on the energy of Australia's teachers who are there to cater for some three million students in this country. This is occurring at a time when I think it is widely acknowledged that governments are retreating from their responsibilities to provide high quality education. You see it in terms of the cutbacks that are occurring at the state level. I see it in my state where some 8,500 teachers have been forced out of the system, where something like 360 schools have closed. The senator from the Northern Territory, Senator Tambling, is in the chamber. I point out that twice the number of schools in the Northern Territory have been closed in the state of Victoria.

We are seeing massive reductions in expenditure being provided on a per capita basis. At the Commonwealth level we are seeing the introduction of enrolment benchmark adjustment mechanisms to transfer resources from the private sector to the public sector. You see the removal of funding through the various FAG agreements—the Commonwealth-state agreements—withdrawing some $400 million from the education system of this country. We have seen the abolition of national professional development programs. You see it in the scrapping of disadvantaged schools programs and various other equity measures by this government.

You see it in attempts being made by conservative politicians, in particular, to use the rhetoric of reform as the basis for presenting a perception of crisis within our educational systems. It is almost as if, in order to justify these massive attacks upon our education systems, conservative politicians in this country are attempting to create the atmosphere of crisis, the atmosphere of failure to legitimise downsizing and cost cutting. It is easier to get away with these attacks upon our education systems if you are able to first present an atmosphere of crisis, rather than have genuine debate about the nature of education in this country.

I noticed, when the senior minister in education was building his empire to remove Senator Vanstone from her place as senior education minister, that some eight weeks after he became the minister for schools he announced in a pre-emptive way that our education systems were failing; that it was a significant proportion of students who were failing to master the basics in literacy. He went on to say that he was going to produce a survey which would demonstrate that there were significant problems in this regard. Is it not surprising, therefore, that when the survey was finally concluded that was exactly what he believed he found. Those remarks were supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who said that the reason we were having difficulties in our schooling system was that of trendy teaching methods. Reminiscent of his views of the good old days, if only we went back into the past, if only we were able to regurgitate the images of the fifties, the problems faced by our education systems could somehow or other be improved.

We saw it in regard to the statements made by Minister Vanstone that public education was the cause of our employment problems. We have seen it in a range of measures taken whereby there has been an attempt made to manipulate data, manipulate surveys, manipulate various information in such a way as to create the impression of crisis within our education system. I note that Dr Kemp put out a press release in which he said:

The system is failing tens of thousands of children. It is feeding the unemployment queue and denying children basic skills to participate fully in society. This situation has been allowed to drift on for far too long.

All of this created the impression that our education system was in crisis. It helped create the environment whereby this government could legitimise its withdrawal of its responsibilities for the public education system in this country. It helped legitimise this government's attacks upon the life experiences of young people in this country as it took from them the real opportunities that can come from a fully integrated quality education program which can only be provided when there is adequate support from governments.

This committee has gone through and highlighted the needs for substantive change in our education system. It has emphasised that there is high quality teaching going on in this country. We do have a high quality education system, and it is not good enough to scapegoat teachers for problems in our society at large. We should acknowledge the successes, commend the successes and, at the same time, acknowledge that there are always ways in which things can be improved.

The key recommendation that this committee comes forward with is the notion of national registration of teaching. The national registration of teaching to me is that important step forward in protecting and improving the integrity of teaching in this country. It provides a vehicle by which we can enhance the standards of teaching. It can provide real growth in professional development. We now have extraordinarily high levels of ageing within our educational systems—the average age of teachers is about 46 years—and many of our teachers have not had access to professional development for many years.

The national registration board can enhance that level of professional development and ensure adequate standards are met by providing a vehicle through which the integrity of our teaching services can be ensured. Given the high levels of mobility that we are facing within this country as a result of population changes it is all the more important for there to be a national approach to these issues, an approach which covers all sections of teaching, from early childhood to government and non-government schools to vocational education and training to TAFE, to ensure that adult and community education is properly accorded its place within the system and that the community can enjoy the benefits of a high quality national approach to the provision of educational services in this country.

I commend this report to the Senate. It is a valuable contribution to the education debate. I note with some disappointment that the Liberal senators on this committee have chosen to take the mealy-mouthed approach that they have in the minority report and move away from the commitments given in regard to the national registration of teachers.

talk.start.para: —I would like to concur with my colleagues who have already spoken on this report by the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee entitled A class act—inquiry into the status of the teaching profession . It is the outcome of a very significant inquiry by the committee. As a teacher, I took great interest in this inquiry and in the hearings and I was able to closely relate to much of the evidence that was presented.

speech.para: The first and probably the easiest recommendation to implement and the one which had the most widespread report—from teachers, unions, academics and principals right across the board—was the establishment of a national registration body which could develop and maintain standards of professional practice. There was overwhelming support for taking this step and a complete absence of any evidence as to why this should not be done. For this reason it is very disappointing that the government members have not seen fit to support that recommendation. They are saying that they support it after a fashion but that it should be up to the states.

It is interesting that we hear that the states have to decide on this particular issue when in other areas, also referred to in the inquiry, we have seen the most interventionist minister for schools possibly in history. It appears that the federal government can introduce national benchmarking and nationwide testing regimes and threaten to remove literacy funding from the states if they do not comply, but the government members do not think we can take that simple step to guarantee the quality of teachers in this country. I hope that the government members will be able to change their minds on this because it is one way in which this committee's work can make a real difference to the status of teachers.
The second recommendation is perhaps the most important of the committee's recommendations and it is that:

. . . governments fund public schools at a level sufficient to deliver the appropriate standard of education within the Eight Key Learning Areas, and commensurate with the National Goals of Schooling.

It says that we need a joint Commonwealth-state education costs committee to examine the real costs of delivering education. Hopefully, this will go some way towards raising the level of resources to schools and to overcome the very debilitating squabbles and buck-passing that we currently see in this area.

As we all know, spending on education has been in decline in real terms for some decades now. As the committee's last report, Not a level playground, showed, more and more parents, teachers and outside organisations are having to provide money for even the most basic educational needs. This is also an important issue for teachers, who are expected not just to teach but to be heavily involved in fundraising for the operation of their schools.
I would like to refer to an excerpt from the report from the Australian Education Union:

It is our view—and it would be recognised by many within the industry as well—that, at the moment, there is not a sufficient proportion of GDP expended on education. It is our view that both the public and private sectors need to be properly resourced so that the kinds of expectations put on schools and on teachers can be fulfilled in a proper way.
We say in our submission that the status of teachers is inextricably linked to the restoration of a properly resourced, high quality system of public education.
They go on to note that in Victoria the budget surplus is around $800 million and yet Victoria spends less per head of population than any other state.

There was a lot of discussion during the inquiry about the enrolment benchmark adjustment and the abandonment of the new schools policy. Witnesses from both the public and the private sectors talked of the divisiveness and the unfair nature of the EBA. For instance, Professor Barry McGraw from the Australian Council of Educational Research commented on the EBA. He said:

My concern is that this is a change of policy that on the face of it looks minor—we shift a bit of money when each student moves. But in aggregate it could be substantial to an extent that people just don't anticipate.

. . . From the point of view of individual choice, lowered barriers to entry and easier movement to private provision has few attractions. From the point of view of quality of Government schooling, there is a serious risk of residualisation.

Parents with a serious commitment to education will be under increased pressure to choose private provision. Those remaining in the public sector are likely to be those with fewer resources and those without the networks and capacities to work for the improvement of the public sector.
The Tasmanian Primary Principals' Association said:

The public v private debate is highly relevant to the matter of teacher status, and particularly the status of that large majority of teachers in the public school system. The debate places their schools and therefore their quality under fire and is a major vehicle for attacks on their professionalism, integrity and performance. It is also a major source of their concerns about the security of their careers. Finally, it threatens, in their eyes, the interests of children.

Many submissions to the inquiry expressed regret at what was called the politicisation of education and the way that teachers were persistently attacked by politicians. Of course, teachers have very few avenues for comeback and so this inquiry was an important opportunity for them to express their anger and their hurt at those attacks. They felt that politicians had a responsibility to show leadership and to defend and support the work that they do, and that politicians were responsible in large measure for the poor standing of teachers in the community. The report says:

. . . the nature of political involvement in education, at least with regard to its impact at the school level, can be narrowly focussed, ill informed, short term and sometimes very damaging in its consequences.
The Mount Lawley High School teachers said:

Our experience has been that the politicisation is present at state level, it is present at federal level and it is present on both sides of politics and that the old educational priorities that were to do with a liberal humanist model, where there was a holistic education of the individual and a whole lot of things that were very commonly accepted, are not even spoken about now.
The Tasmanian Principals Association said:

Perhaps the greatest effect on teacher morale arises from the continuing politicisation of education. The present drive for education to serve the needs of the economy strikes at the very heart of the professional teacher's ideals and the view of education and children's interests which stems from those ideals.

As might be expected, literacy was also a very big issue in this inquiry and it came up time and time again in that context of politicisation. The Senate will recall Dr Kemp saying our literacy and numeracy levels in Australia were a `national disgrace' and he blamed it on teachers' failure to devote sufficient time to teaching basics and on their lack of skills and training. I might add that this is the same minister who removed funding from the professional development program for teachers in the last budget. Our Prime Minister blamed the results on `faddish' teaching methods.

Those of us who visit schools regularly and talk to teachers know that this is really a load of nonsense. There is little doubt that teachers need to continually upgrade their skills, particularly in the fields of literacy at the primary level. Such professional development should be an ongoing part of our education system, and I think we all understand that. It is in many schools but others just do not have the resources to make that possible.

The report also calls for the reinstatement of the disadvantaged schools program. That, of course, would go some way to address this need. The report identifies weaknesses in teacher training and induction and it makes recommendations about the way forward, including reinstatement of the successful national schools network. The report calls for a reversal of the trend to put teachers on short-term contracts. In Victoria schools are expected to get 40 per cent of their staff on contract, and the message through this to teachers is very clear: we do not value you and your experience; you are expendable. Whilst this may save money—I understand it is not unknown for teachers to be employed on a term-by-term basis and therefore not get their annual leave—it is also very damaging for teacher morale and is simply exploitative. If we want teachers to be professional, we must be very careful in the way that we treat them and, in my view, putting them on contracts is not one way to do that.

I would like to conclude by thanking the secretariat for producing this fine document. I commend it to the Senate. It is a very good read. It is the result of a great deal of effort on the part of the committee, the secretariat and, of course, all of those people who made submissions and took the trouble to come along and talk to the inquiry.
Debate (on motion by Senator Troeth) adjourned.
